Nov 30th 1878
Hon Karl Schurz
Secty of the Interior

 Sir
In the report of Genl Randolph B. Marcy of the Inspector Genls Office,

upon Indian Affairs - As published in the N.Y. Tribune of yesterday - I notice
some statements of such an erroneous character, that I feel impelled to call attention
to them.

In speaking of the present "dual management" of the Indians - as he terms it, the Genl says,

small newspaper article attached:
...military post may be established in the vicinity of an Indian agency for the protection of Indian officials and soon after the buildings
are completed the agent may think proper to change the location of the agency to some smudged there? making  necessary new buildings, smudged for the smudged but for the troops. A case was reported one of the smudged of my Department where smudged of the Apache in Arizona, for reasons ? known only to himself removed his agency as far ? a con?? military post as he deemed it consistent with smudged per own salary, and ordered all the buildings, valued at $20,000, to be burned to the ground as soon as the Indians left. At the same time he knew that the lumber was greatly needed for repairing the quarters at the adjacent p?t.

2
In this statement he first assumed that an Indian Agent may change the location of Agency at will. When in fact,  he possesses no greater power, at most to effect such change - than is conferred on the commandant of a military post, to secure changes of location.  Such authority is vested solely in the head of the Department of the Interior.

 As I have recently returned from a tour of inspection, embracing all of the Agencies in the South West, - I should know if "for reasons best known to himself", any agent in that section, had removed his Agency "as far from a contiguous military post as he deemed consistent with his own safety", and ordered Govt buildings - valued at $20,000 to be burned.
 I know of no such instance, either in Arizona - or elsewhere.

3
The only Agency buildings that have been burned in Arizona, were a portion of those connected with the old Chiricahua Agency - which I presumed to be the ones to which the Genl. refers.   The removal of the Indians and the fire occurred under the following circumstances.

 For years the Apaches of Arizona and New Mexico had been hostile, and despite the efforts of military, had continued to roam through mountain portions of these Territories, - retarding the development of the rich mines with which the country abounds; and rendering life and property insecure. Up to the winter of 1875-6, the Indians management had established four Agencies for the Apaches of this region, namely - Camp Verde in the

4
Northern part of the Territory of Arizona.

- San Carlos in the interior, Chiricahua in the Southern, and Ojo Caliente in Western New Mexico. Adjacent to each of these Agencies, and at other points in the country, military posts, or camps, were also established. Still the Indians were troublesome. Constant war prevailed, and consequent danger, and loss of life, to prospectors and settlers.
 After careful consideration of this situation, the Indian management decided to consolidate the Indians, on the San Carlos reservation, and attempt their control through the instrumentality of an Indian Police. The San Carlos reserve, - being well up among the mountains, and watered by the Gila and San Carlos rivers, - was by far the best location to be found, in

5
the country - and Agent Clum, then the agent at San Carlos - was peculiarly qualified to superintend the work of consolidation. Accordingly - he was authorized to organize a force of thirty Indians - (which was afterwards  increased to fifty) - from the White mountain, and San Carlos bands of Apaches - and directed to remove the Indians from Camp Verde, Ojo Caliente, and Chiricahua to the San Carlos reserve.  How well, and thorough he accomplished this work - the records of the Indian office will show. With his Indian Police, with but little, -if any - assistance from the military - And at slight cost to the Government, he moved these bands of Apaches to San Carlos. There they have since remained, - peaceful and quiet. And are now much interested in

6
farming and stock raising - and rapidly becoming self-supporting. They number about 4500. As the result of keeping the Indians quiet, the country has developed more in the last eighteen months than in all the intervening years - since the Gadsden purchase.     After Agent Clum had started the Indians from Chiricahua Agency, and was well on the road toward San Carlos, a portion of the Agency buildings were burned - set on fire, either accidentally or purposely - (which is not known) by some white men who were camping then.

 I am aware, that at this time, certain military officers - who interfered to make the movement a failure - circulated the report that the buildings were burned by Agent Clums direction. But I hear

7
never been able to find any proof - corroboration of these statements, Certainly I can conceive of no motive for such action. The buildings, however, were  cheap log structures, and instead of costing $20,000 - those burned - probably, did not cost a tenth of that sum. - And would not have sold for anything - beyond a mere nominal price, - after the Indians were removed.

 The Genls quotation from the Indian Commissioners report for 1876 - which he stigmatizes as "eminently puerile, and absurd" - if I mistake not is the language of a report, made by a commission - composed largely of Army officers - And is said to have been written by a very distinguished Officer - of high rank. Doubtless this fact had escaped the Genls observation,

8
This General pays a merited compliment to the Board of Indian Commissioners - and implies that the only examination or  inspections , at Agencies - are made by them, and generously excuses them for failure "to exercise much control" over Agents. It would seem the Genl is not aware that the law provides for these inspectors of Indian Affairs, who are clothed with ample authority, and whose duty it is, to visit the Agencies, inspect books - account, supplies - and all matters pertaining to the Indian service. These reports to the Department are largely confidential, and are not published. But they are kept constantly at work, and investigate not only "charges against Agents" - of which there are many - (nine tenths of which, however,

9
are without foundation) but the general management.

 During the war of the rebellion I had some little experience as an Army inspector, - both with volunteer and regular troops. And during my - nearly - four years service as an Indian inspector, I have visited very many frontier posts, and come in contact with numerous Army officers and I think these gentlemen will generally bear me out in the statement, that inspections - as at present  conducted in the Indian service, - for thoroughness and care, will compare favorably with like examinations - under the military branch of our public service.
 I depricate the looseness -

10
with which some of our Army friends, make statements in regard to Indian Agents  - and the Indian management.

 In their zeal to secure the transfer of the Bureau - I fear they are led to embellish their Imblications with more or less fiction.
  Very Respectfully
  Your Obt Servt
  E.C. Watkins
  U.S. Ind. Inspector

3
Washington D.C.
